p.value: Materials are open without restrictions, with the exception of certain files pertaining to legal proceedings in Series IV.
Donated by Ciarán O'Reilly in June 2016.  The accession number associated with this gift is 2016.055.

Items of little research value were deaccessioned, including personal financial documents related to performers and customers, files related to staff performance, unopened commercial recordings of music and audiobooks unrelated to the Irish Repertory Theatre, clippings of reviews, Zip and floppy disks containing graphic design files used to create promotional ephemera for productions, and Theatre souvenirs.  Off-air recordings of reviews of IRT productions were deaccessioned.
The records are arranged into the following four series, with two of these series further arranged into subseries.
Series I. Production Materials, 1989-2016
Series II. New Works Reading Series, 2005-2014
Subseries II. A. Selected Plays, 2006-2014
Subseries II. B. Rejected Script Files, 2005-2014
Series III. Administrative Records, 1990-2013
Subseries III. A. General Administrative Records, 1990-2013
Subseries III. B. Producing Director Records, 1994-2003
Subseries III. C. General Manager Records, 1997-2004
Subseries III. D. Membership Manager Records, 1999-2004
Subseries III.E. Marketing Department Records, 2003-2016
Series IV. Financial and Legal Records, 1989-2010

The Irish Repertory Theatre (IRT) was founded in New York, New York in 1988 by Charlotte Moore and Ciarán O'Reilly. As of 2018, Moore is the Artistic Director and O'Reilly is the Managing Director. The two met in the late 1980s in a Hudson Guild Theater production of Hugh Leonard's Summer, and decided to collaborate on a production of Sean O'Casey's The Plough and the Stars in September 1988. Their profits from that production were enough to stage another show, and in this way the IRT was founded. The IRT produces Irish and Irish-American plays and musicals year-round, both classics of Irish theater as well as new works by emerging Irish and Irish-American writers. The Theatre moved to its current location, as of 2018, in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan in 1995. The IRT, its staff, and their productions have garnered critical acclaim and industry awards for their work.

p.value: The collection was transferred to Bobst Library from the Irish Repertory Theatre offices at 132 West 22nd Street, New York, NY 10011 on June 30, 2016.  It was arranged by season, boxed and inventoried by Jessica Layman (Director of Marketing), in consultation with Lisa Fane (General Manager).  Much of the collection was in temporary storage with The Padded Wagon, in the company's temporary offices at 345 Park Avenue, 17th floor, NYC, or in the company's temporary performance space at Theatre DR2, 103 East 15th Street while their permanent home was under renovation from 2014-2016.

abstract.value: The Irish Repertory Theatre (IRT) was founded in New York, New York in 1988 by Charlotte Moore and Ciarán O'Reilly. The IRT produces Irish and Irish-American plays and musicals year-round. The Irish Repertory Theatre Records document 28 seasons of productions, from 1988 to 2016. Productions include The Plough and the Stars, The Irish...And How They Got That Way, and Finian's Rainbow. The records contain press and marketing materials, correspondence, scripts, legal documents, financial documents, original artwork, video recordings, and posters. The material consists of paper, born-digital, and audiovisual material.

extent.value: in 32 manuscript boxes, 2 half manuscript box, 10 record cartons, 1 flat box, 3 oversize flat boxes, and 1 flat file folder

extent.value: in 14 manuscript boxes, 2 record cartons, 3 oversize flat boxes

p.value: This series documents 28 seasons of the Irish Repertory Theatre's productions and annual benefits, from 1989 to 2016. Material in this series consists of paper, born-digital, and audiovisual formats and includes promotional material, photographs, artwork, and material pertaining to legal and creative issues from early productions. The promotional material includes programs, postcards, posters, and press releases for individual productions; tickets, invitations, and programs for annual benefits; and issues of Prologue, the IRT's newsletter. The audiovisual material consists of video and digital audio and video recordings of select productions, including George M. Cohan Tonight!, Noctu, The Irish...And How They Got That Way, and annual benefits. Most productions are well documented through digital and print photographs and slides. Artwork includes drawings for set designs and posters.
This series is arranged in two subseries, Subseries II. A. Selected Plays and Subseries II.B. Rejected Script Files.
This subseries is arranged in chronological order by year and month in which the plays were performed by the IRT.
This subseries includes scripts chosen as part of the New Works Readings Series.
The files in this subseries are loosely arranged in numerical order according to numbers assigned to each script as it was received by the Literary Department.

unittitle.value: Subseries II. B. Rejected Script Files

p.value: This subseries consists of script files submitted for the New Works Readings Series that were rejected by the IRT. The files include scripts, cover letters, curricula vitae, correspondence with authors, and reader reports.
This series documents the work of the Literary Department in evaluating submitted scripts and choosing works for the New Works Reading Series. Material in this series consists entirely of paper.

This series is arranged in five subseries:  Subseries III. A. General Administrative Records, Subseries III. B. Producing Director Records, Subseries III. C. General Manager Records, Subseries III. D. Membership Manager Records, and Subseries III.E. Marketing Department Records.
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by format or topic.

Subseries III. A. General Administrative Records

p.value: This subseries documents the IRT's cooperation with labor unions representing performers in New York City and the work of  the IRT's Board of Directors.  This subseries includes correspondence and contracts.  Labor unions include the Actors' Equity Association, the United Scenic Artists, Local 802 Associated Musicians of Greater New York, and the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society.  Material documenting the work of the Board includes correspondence and meeting agenda and minutes.
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by production title, topic, or format of material.

Subseries III. B. Producing Director Records

p.value: This subseries documents the work of Ciarán O'Reilly, co-founder and Producing Director of the IRT. Materials consists of paper and born-digital material and includes correspondence, budgets, notes, box office reports, and scripts. Correspondence includes negotiations with the Actors' Equity Association, requests for and acknowledgements of financial support for productions and the IRT, and licensing for scripts. This subseries contains material regarding the production of Grandchild of Kings, a production adapted from Sean O'Casey's autobiographies, directed by Harold Prince. This subseries also includes letters from O'Reilly to IRT members and sponsors, labor unions, and directors of productions at the IRT, including Tony Walton and Frank McCourt.
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by production title, topic, format, or by the name of file's creator.

unittitle.value: Subseries III. C. General Manager Records

p.value: This subseries documents the work of two of the General Managers of the IRT, Shelley A. Troupe and Meridith Sommers.  Responsibilities of this role documented in this subseries include managing day-to-day activities of the IRT, organizing the IRT's annual benefit, participating in advertising and development campaigns, managing the box office, and tracking compliance with the Actor's Equity Association (AEA) contracts.  Material in this subseries consists of paper and born-digital material and includes correspondence, budgets, audits, contracts, photographs, box office reports, meeting agenda and minutes, and promotional material.  This subseries includes Board of Directors meeting agenda and minutes and correspondence with the AEA, IRT members and sponsors, vendors, and insurance providers.
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by topic.

This subseries documents the work of two of Membership Managers of the IRT, Heather Kray and Eric Scott.  Responsibilities of this role documented in this subseries include maintaining relationships with current theatre members as well as with advertisers.  This subseries consists entirely of born-digital material and includes correspondence, spreadsheets, and promotional material.
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by production title, format, or topic.

unittitle.value: The Picture of Dorian Gray
The Shadow of a Gunman

p.value: This subseries documents the work of the Marketing Department, including branding, promotion of the IRT and its productions, development of the capital campaign to renovate the theatre from 2014 to 2016, and the creation of a new website in 2012.  The material in this subseries consists of paper and born-digital material and includes correspondence, promotional material, spreadsheets, photographs, blueprints, floor plans, and artwork.  This subseries contains the Marketing Department's archive of promotional material for individual productions for seasons 2003-2004 to 2016-2017, material detailing the creation of the IRT's new website in 2012, guidelines for IRT branding standards, and artwork used in the creation of promotional material.  Material detailing the development of the capital campaign includes a brochure and statement regarding the campaign, photographs and videos used to promote the campaign, and photographs of the theatre before, during, and after the renovation.

extent.value: in 5 manuscript boxes and 1 oversize flat box

p.value: This series documents various administrative offices and activities of the IRT, including the Producing Director, the General Manager, the Membership Manager, and the Marketing Department.  Material in this series consists of both paper and born-digital material and includes correspondence, reports, budgets, photographs, and blueprints and floor plans.
Two folders in this series are protected under the attorney work-product doctrine.  They was separated from the collection in March 2018 pending a decision regarding its inclusion in the collection.
This series is arranged alphabetically by format or topic.

unittitle.value: The Irish…And How They Got That Way

p.value: Material in box 42 is restricted.

unittitle.value: Reilly, Charles Nelson -- Save It for the Stage
State of New York Department of Law
Series IV. Financial and Legal Records

p.value: This series documents legal proceedings in which the IRT was involved, financial audits, and renovation of the IRT in 1995. This series consists of paper material and includes correspondence, contracts, court documents, audits, blueprints, and the IRT's by-laws and certificate of incorporation. Legal proceedings documented in this series include suits brought by the IRT against producer Robert Macken regarding his production of video recordings of The Irish...and How They Got That Way and Fathers to Daughters, and a suit brought by Charles Nelson Reilly against producer Michael Alden regarding Save It for the Stage: The Life of Reilly. The financial materials document the production of The Irish...and How They Got That Way and its 1997-1998 tour in New York City and Boston, Massachusetts; production budgets and box office totals for other IRT productions; and annual IRT audits. Material regarding the IRT's renovation include correspondence with the architect and blueprints detailing the renovation.

Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact [repository contact information] with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

Advance notice is required for the use of computer records.  Original physical digital media is restricted.  An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.
Identification of item, date; Irish Repertory Theatre Records; AIA 080; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

Series were created according to the arrangement in which the collection was received and material was arranged together intellectually.  Paper material for each series was brought together physically, with oversized paper materials, audiovisual material, and physical digital media housed together as appropriate.  Separation sheets were created to sustain the intellectual relationship between items.

Paper material was housed in archival folders and boxes.  Physical digital media and audiovisual material were housed in archival boxes.  Duplicates in all formats were deaccessioned.  Preservation photocopies were created for material originally printed on thermal fax paper.

Material in Series IV was determined to be protected under the attorney work-product doctrine.  This was separated from the collection in March 2018 pending a decision regarding its inclusion in the collection.

In August 2019, duplicate material and off-air recordings were returned to the donor.
Floppy disks, Zip disks, optical media, and one hard drive were forensically imaged, analyzed, and arranged in Forensic Toolkit.
New York University Libraries follows professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity of the content.

The Irish Repertory Theatre (IRT) Records document 28 seasons of productions staged by the Theatre, from 1988 to 2016. Productions include The Plough and the Stars, The Irish...And How They Got That Way, and Finian's Rainbow. The records document the work of various members and departments of the IRT, including Ciaran O'Reilly, the Producing Director; the Marketing Department; the General Manager; the Literary Department; and the Membership Manager. The records contain press and marketing materials, correspondence, scripts, legal documents, financial documents, original artwork, videos, and posters. The material consists of paper, born-digital, and audiovisual recordings. The press and marketing materials constitute the bulk of the collection and include programs, press releases, photographs, slides, and video recordings of productions and the IRT's annual benefits. The correspondence includes rejection letters; negotiations for rights, licensing, and productions; and communications with actors, producers, directors, and IRT members. The collection includes scripts used in productions and those submitted for the New Works Reading Series. The legal documents include contracts as well as court documents from legal proceedings in which the IRT was involved. The financial records include season and production budgets, and box office receipts and statements. The original artwork includes paintings and drawings for set designs and posters.
One recording of The Irish...And How They Got That Way on VHS was transferred to the Avery Fisher Center in July 2018.

Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the Irish Repertory Theatre, the creator of this collection, were transferred to New York University in June 2016 by Ciarán O'Reilly. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library.
